review:
In a world that thrives on division, it becomes increasingly important to find common ground, to unite under shared passions and experiences. Blizzard Entertainment's Overwatch 2, the long-awaited sequel to the beloved team-based shooter, has now graced the digital shelves of Steam, presenting a golden opportunity for gamers across the spectrum to stand together and celebrate the power of collaboration, competition, and creativity.

Overwatch 2, with its vibrant characters and immersive gameplay, has captured the hearts of millions. The game's arrival on Steam is not just a technical achievement but a symbolic one. It signifies the willingness of Blizzard Entertainment to embrace a wider audience and forge connections beyond its traditional platforms. This move encourages unity among players, as fans from different backgrounds can now rally behind the game's diverse roster of heroes, fostering a sense of camaraderie that transcends borders and differences.

Blizzard Entertainment's commitment to refining Overwatch 2 based on player feedback demonstrates their dedication to creating a truly exceptional gaming experience. The Steam launch provides an additional channel for players to share their thoughts, contributing to the game's ongoing development. By supporting the game on Steam, the gaming community can directly influence its evolution, fostering an environment where developers and players work collaboratively to craft a masterpiece that reflects the desires of all involved.

Furthermore, embracing Overwatch 2 on Steam can bridge gaps between various gaming communities. The game's popularity extends across the globe, attracting players from different cultures and backgrounds. Through Steam, these players can come together, sharing strategies, stories, and laughter, forming connections that transcend linguistic and cultural barriers. This unity forged by Overwatch 2 exemplifies the positive potential of gaming, breaking down prejudices and fostering friendships that might have never flourished otherwise.

Let's not forget the economic impact of supporting Blizzard Entertainment's Overwatch 2 on Steam. A thriving gaming industry benefits everyone involved, from the developers who pour their creativity into the game to the players who derive joy from it. By rallying behind this launch, players contribute to the growth of a passionate community that sustains careers, drives innovation, and ensures the continuation of cherished franchises. This kind of support sends a strong message that the gaming community values creativity, hard work, and dedication.

Overwatch 2's Steam launch can also act as a catalyst for other studios to consider cross-platform initiatives. The success of this move might encourage other developers to explore new avenues for reaching wider audiences. This could potentially lead to a more interconnected gaming landscape, where players can enjoy their favorite titles regardless of the platform they choose, promoting a sense of inclusion and acceptance.

In conclusion, the arrival of Blizzard Entertainment's Overwatch 2 on Steam is more than just a game launch; it's an opportunity for gamers around the world to stand together and celebrate the values that make gaming special. By supporting this initiative, players are not only embracing a beloved franchise but also advocating for unity, diversity, and collaboration within the gaming community. The impact of such solidarity reaches beyond virtual worlds, fostering connections, friendships, and shared experiences that enrich our lives. As we embark on this new chapter in gaming, let us remember that by supporting one another, we create a brighter and more inclusive future for all.

Just the most sad collection of poor decisions that I have ever seen in an online game, each update more disappointing than the last. Return on investment doesn't exist rip - 2022-2023. 

You can't just make a good game and sell it anymore according to Blizzard.

If the original concept and foundation that OW1 made wasn't so damn strong and fun on a fundamental level, this game would've fallen into obscurity. The game launched with less content than 1 and was called 2 then they slowly gave you most of the stuff back from the previous game (maps, custom game modes, arcade, pve). 

Then they try to make you pay for the pve game mode that they promised and couldn't finish developing, so you pay ¬£12.99 for 3 pve maps and skins and coins to buy more skins. They make a huge deal about the free seasonal content that they release over the course of the year only for the skins that you used to be able to earn by playing the events to be locked behind paywalls or the battlepass. Which they have now implemented into the game because buying the base game then earning the skins by playing was too much to ask for, or paying a reasonable amount of money for some loot boxes to get a bunch of skins wasn't making them enough money I guess.  

The pricing on the content on the shop is extortionate and it takes ages of playing the game normally to unlock 1 single skin, sometimes and I mean rarely do they make a skin really cheap so anyone can buy it, but I'm not going to thank them for that when the rest of the game is a husk of what it used to be. 

The control point, escort and hybrid (control point and escort combined) modes are great and always have been but the new push mode is extremely tedious and makes for long and confusing matches which are arguably unbalanced (watch this video if you want to know why). https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lYi5eCxHke8&ab_channel=GamerMaths 

The game's balancing relies on whatever new character they add into the game and how busted they are at launch and by the time you can unlock the new character by buying it through the battlepass, buying it outright or by unlocking it slowly 
for free through the free lesser battlepass, they will have changed the meta of the game and have tweaked the new character and others to balance the game out (hopefully). This isn't the best, but being able to get the new characters for free EVENTUALLY through the free battlepass is ok, not good but ok and they will never perfectly balance a game like this so it's something that I can forgive. But only to an extent because to be fair a game like this with so many different characters and 3 roles to balance is gonna be chaotic.

For Free to play players you have to unlock all the characters by playing, compared to when you just bought the game OW1 when it originally came out. This is good and bad because, this way more people play the game but bad because the quality of the players in the game is very VERY hit and miss. People will avoid accountability on this game like it's the plague, it's always someone else's fault so the community of this game is either very toxic, or just oblivious to their own shortcomings and I LOVE IT I enjoy it a lot, what is said in the game stays in the game people!

They added a new flashpoint mode which is what I would describe as king of the hill from Halo, 3 points on the map that have to be captured in order and two teams battle it out to score 3 points whoever gets all 3 wins. It's really fun and I don't know the cons of the mode yet or weather or not it's imbalanced but I genuinely like it and I am having a good time playing it in comp. 

To summarise this game is the definition of a rabbit running on a treadmill with a carrot dangling above it's head constantly running towards something but never fully achieving it, that's what the development process for this game seems like, one step forward three steps back...

I have 959 hours on my Blizz account for this game (Overwatch 1 & 2) by the time of writing this and my highest rank is (plat 1 dps), I dabble with Tank (plat 5) and I'm starting to enjoy helping people as a support class, although I'm mainly a dps. 

It's one of the most entertaining games that I've ever played and I wrote this because I do genuinely love the game, it's just a very very complicated game with a lot of issues that I wish were handled better, here's to the future. <3
